stimulusHtml:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.


The manufacturer of a certain sports drink is interested in examining the hydration habits of the large number of consumers of its sports drink product. The manufacturer sent an e-mail survey to each consumer who bought the product through the manufacturer’s website in the previous month that asked consumers to respond to the question, “Do you usually consume at least one sports drink per day?”

(a) Explain how the manufacturer’s sampling method might have introduced bias and describe how the bias might affect the point estimate of p, the proportion of all consumers of the sports drink who would respond “yes” to the question.

Suppose that 78% of consumers of the sports drink consume at least one sports drink per day. Let G represent the total number of consumers of the sports drink selected at random, one at a time, from the consumers of the product when the first consumer who consumes at least one sports drink per day is selected. The graph shows the probability distribution of G.

(b) Calculate and interpret the expected value of G.
(c) Describe a simulation process that could be conducted to estimate the value of P(1<G≤3).

The owner of a sports wellness store that sells the sports drink product is interested in examining whether its 1,000 customers who regularly purchase the sports drink have different hydration habits from the overall population of consumers of the sports drink. A random sample of 80 customers who regularly purchase the sports drink will be selected from the store’s sales records and each customer will be asked to report whether they usually consume at least one sports drink per day.

(d) If the owner uses a stratified random sampling procedure to select the sample, identify an effective variable on which to stratify. Explain your reasoning.

Assume the conditions for inference are met. A 96 percent confidence interval for the proportion of all customers of this store who regularly purchase the sports drink who would report that they usually consume at least one sports drink per day was computed to be 0.825±0.087.

(e) Does the confidence interval provide convincing statistical evidence that the customers of this store who regularly purchase the sports drink have different hydration habits from the overall population of consumers of the sports drink? Justify your answer.
